176 to 187 South Street, north side, east from and including Roosevelt Street to James Slip. This scene, northward from the Brooklyn Bridge shows also a general view to Foley Square with it's civic structures.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A similar view at an earlier date. Shown on the right is a view northward on the east side of James Slip to Cherry Street.
November 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

173 and 174 South Street (the old numbers, seen on the picture, were, respectively, 174 and 175 until 1891, according to the C.W. Bromley real estate map of that year. The succeeding map of 1897 and all others that have followed until the present day, 1937, designate the two houses by the new numbers), adjoining and at the S.W. corner of Roosevelt Street. Also shown is No. 133 Roosevelt Street a 4-story loft building at the S.E. corner of Front Street. A portion of the Brooklyn Bridge can be seen in the left background. No. 173 (old No. 174) is the house in which Alfred E. Smith was born on December 30, 1873. He served four terms as Governor of the State of New York and was Democratic candidate for President in 1928. Long in New York City and State politics, he is often referred to as "New York's own Al Smith." He is a leading figure in the Society of Tammany and is one of the organizers of the Liberty League, an organization of leading industrialists and bankers of extremely conservative leanings in politics. Born and raised in the city slums, he had no more than a parochial school education. In later life, as a public personality he received several degrees as Doctor of Laws from Harvard, Columbia, Fordham, and other famous universities.

About 1925.

Brown Brothers.

131-125 Roosevelt Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of Front Street. Also shown, is No. 290 Front Street, (5-story house on left), adjoining the N.W. corner of Roosevelt Street. The corner house (is No. 131) Roosevelt Street.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Roosevelt Street, west side, north from Water, to Cherry Streets. In the foreground, is a 3-story frame house, No. 318 Water Street. The 4-story building in the foreground, is No. 45 Cherry Street, at the S.W. corner of Roosevelt Street. The three 3-story buildings in the center of the view, are Nos. 115 to 111 Roosevelt Street.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

South Street, west side, south from and including Roosevelt Street. The 4-story house in the foreground, is No. 133 Roosevelt Street, at the S.W. corner of Front (extreme right) Streets. Also shown is a portion of the Brooklyn Bridge.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, from a point slightly southward. Also shown (left to right), are the Farmer's Loan and Trust Co. Building, 60 Wall Street Tower, and Bank of Manhattan Trust Co. Building.

June 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Water Street, west from and including Roosevelt, to but not including Dover Streets. The building on the N.W. corner is a frame house. The Brooklyn Bridge is seen in the background. Also shown is Roosevelt Street, at Water Street. Note the Jerry McAuley Mission at Nos. 312-314, west of Roosevelt Street. The buildings on either side of said Mission are 1-story structures. Water Street changes its direction to run arbitrarily north and south when south of the Brooklyn Bridge.
September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
320 Water Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Roosevelt Street. Building shown is a 1-story frame structure. Note new building occupying the corner site, formerly a 3-story frame house. On the left appears a portion of the Jerry McAuley Mission.
1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(3)
ASSUMING STREET
Similar to No. 1.

Water Street, north side, east from and including Roosevelt Street. (Direction of Water Street is arbitrarily set to run east and west from the Brooklyn Bridge to East Street.
April 15, 1932.

349 Water Street, south side, between Roosevelt Street and James Slip. Building shown is a frame shack. (Direction of Water Street is arbitrarily set to run east and west from the Brooklyn Bridge to East Street).

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

176, 177 and 178 South Street, (right), at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Roosevelt Street. Also shown, are Nos. 292, 290, 288, and a portion of No. 284 Front Street (left), at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Roosevelt Street. (South Street, at this point, (foot of Roosevelt Street), makes a sharp turn southward, as seen in the left foreground. In the center of the view is shown, Roosevelt Street, west side, north from and including Front Street. The tower of the Municipal building is discernible in the background.

June 22, 1933.

The view shows from left to right, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Woolworth Building, the Municipal Building and the new Federal Courts Building.

March 30, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Front Street - Roosevelt and Dover Streets
text:
(1)
Front Street, north side, west from, but not including Roosevelt, to and including Dover Streets, as seen under the Brooklyn Bridge.

October 24, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A limited view of buildings directly under the bridge.

October 24, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
